title: Folding Guitar Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This folding guitar stand is actually attached to your guitar. Folded up, it does not impede with your guitar playing, but once you need to put your guitar down, just pull out the support legs and you can safely place your guitar on the ground. Great between gigs!

There are two main sets to print:
  • Angry Japanese elephant - there are two choices, one with 30 degree (max) angle per leg, and the other with 45 degree; chose one that will fit your guitar.
  • The Rest - Assorted parts for assembly (see instructions below)
    • Assembly: Angry Japanese elephant:
  • Bolt the two 'tusks' to the angry elephant using M3x16 bolts
    • The Rest:
  • Glue together the two sets: The support arm between the legs and the small peg with the M3 hole, and the strut assembly (2 parts) - see pic for more details.
    • Bolt everything together using 2 M3x16 bolts The Angry Japanese elephant and the leg holder (the last piece from the Rest pieces) should be secured to the guitar back using double sided tape. I used 4.76mm (3/16) aluminium rods for the legs - should you be using anything else, please readjust the holes in the elephant tusks and the gaps in the support arms in the provided Sketchup files.

author: juniortan

title: Q U A K E ]I[ A R E N A Klesk

description.text: "It is what we do. It is destiny. It is joy." — Klesk, while chasing its prey Klesk is one of the many playable characters in Quake 3 Arena. Klesk is an alien mystic, a religious zealot but as it is an Arena Lord of Tier 3, terrifies all but oneself at Hell's Gate (q3tourney3); it is a challenge. Hell's Gate, is a tight map centered around the Railgun and Plasma Gun fights. He prefers the Railgun, but will go for the Rocket Launcher or the Plasma Gun if he gets the chance. He will fall back on the Shotgun if he needs to. His own tourney map includes Battle Suit but he favors Regeneration more if skirmish map has it. It is a Chitinid alien (which are hive-minded creatures), and has large metallic spikes protruding from his back. Blood stains on claws and spikes are noticeable and contrasted with its gold yellow skin. Its other names on chat lines are; "Bug", "Scum-sucker" and "corpse-gobbler".

description.text: This is a ramp to go from the floor to standard wooden track.  This works with many popular wooden train track sets.

title: Q U A K E ]I[ A R E N A  Lucy

description.text:
Lucy appears in and is a playable character in Quake 3 Arena. She is an enemy warrior in Tier 4 in the singleplayer mode of Quake 3 Arena. She favors the Rocket Launcher and BFG10K.
Quake III biography Edit A former prison guard, Lucy crossed the line and ended up on the other side of the bars where every hour was a battle for survival.
Lucy was a guard at a prison solely for men. During a prison break, she used her guns a bit too indiscriminately... mostly against the escapees, but some particularly unpopular guards also died under mysterious circumstances. Her father taught her to shoot. The rest of her repertoire is pure improv.[1]

title: Q U A K E ]I[ A R E N A Crash

description.text:
Crash is the tutorial bot who introduces the player to Quake 3 Arena. This game is a easy game with the first to five frags to win. Also this bot does actually speak to you. Well it seems to. The bot has a auto taunt program that every time you say something to her she says something random back. She is the only bot which does this.
Quake III biography Edit Once, she was Doom's military instructor. Now the Arena Eternal tests Crash's mettle to the extreme-extreme patience, that is. She is the trainer who introduces new warriors to the skills of battle.[1]
StrategyEdit Crash puts your battle skills to test at the very start of the game. You'll spawn in a single room with a mirror and a teleporter. This room also has a Yellow Armor, a Shotgun and some 5 Health bonuses. The room also has a mirroring teleporter which will teleport you to your first eternal arena. As you step in the actual map, keep the Yellow Armor room to your left in control, stay out of her way when she enters the little Shotgun room just infront of you, as she will get out with an accurate blast. Getting the Plasma Gun may help while trying to keep the Yellow Armor spawnpoint under control. You can weaken her with a few rounds of the Machine Gun (Q3) then do the finishing touch by switching back to the Shotgun. If you keep losing to her try to do a role change and try to keep the Shotgun room under control then slip to the Yellow Armor room. Like Bones, Crash prefers the Shotgun all the time. Even if she picks up other weapons, she does not change them.

Printed as one solid outline of ABS, but thin and flexible, mainly to keep noise from transferring between the bottom board of my oversized mendel to the hollow wooden table it's sitting on.

It's three cylinders, with slightly smaller cylinders subtracted out of them, connected by a rectangle with it's guts subtracted out too. I left the bottom portion of the middle circle because I thought it looked cooler that way. :)

A mount which allows me to mount my radio onto my paraglider.
It uses the radios beltclip to attach to a 25mm tube.
Both straight and 45 deg mounts are here as stl. Both have channels embedded into the mount for zip-ties. Added April 2015 - radio-mount-bfeng.stl

radio-mount-bfeng.stl has hole for a DIN-6 socket. DIN-8 should also work.
There are holes for flower nuts for the DIN mounting screws.
These are the smaller M3 flower nuts - about 4mm across.
The larger ones aren't goint to work.
Getting the nuts into place so they can be pulled home using M3 screws is challenging. I used curved forceps to hold them.
A cable tie on the cable will stop the cable being pulled enough to damage the DIN wiring.

Used to help apply kapton tape to a glass build plate.
I uploaded a .stl file, but you don't want to print one.  Use foamboard or wood.

This tool is very useful.  It allows you to align the tape and apply it without bubbles.  
I made mine out of foamboard.  It just needs to be thicker than the glass.  I put kapton tape on the ends to give the tape something to stick to that would not tear the foamboard.
Stretch kapton tape between the ends.  Work with it until it is even on all four corners.
With the glass build plate on a flat surface, put the tool over it and align the tape where you want it.  It should not be touching the glass.
Use a credit card and start in the middle and push the tape on the glass.  From the middle to the edge.
Use an exato knife to cut the tape along the edge of the glass. 
Outside dimensions 305mm x 15mm.  Inner dimensions 230mm x 115mm.

comments.text: Another trick: Use a soapy sponge to wet down the sticky side before applying tape. It keeps it from sticking as much until you've had time to situate it. Then let it dry overnight and it'll be smooth as glass and as suck as ever.
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: Good idea! Replacing Kapton is such a pain.

These DVMs are under $4 on dx. http://www.dx.com/p/dd63-diy-0-28-3-digit-green-light-led-digital-voltmeter-black-287339#.UzZPkqJ7Yj8

I used poster tape and screws to attach the DVM.
I replaced tht wires and ran them through the hole on the mount for robustness. Polymorph tidied it up a bit.
It is tempting to waterproof it but I won't do so until I see how hot it gets - it may require air flow for cooling.
I only want to measure the supply so I only need two wires.

I'm in the process of building the Solar Tracker designed by opensourceclassroom, but I did not like how the gears were supposed to attach the servos. So I designed a new vertical servo gear that has a hole going all the way through the gear as well as small pilot holes to mount the plastic arms from the servo directly to the gear.
Use a 2mm x 16mm machine screw to directly attach the gear to the servo. This screw should fit perfectly through the hole in the gear.

title: Printrbot Printrboard cooling fan bar mount

description.text: This thing allows you to mount a 70mm (OD) PC cooling fan to the back 2 bars of a Printrbot, thus blowing air across the Printrboard (specifically the stepper drivers). While I haven't heard any reports of Printrboards failing, I wanted to prolong the life of mine as long as possible. I run the fan directly off 5V from an ATX - it is a 12V fan so at this potential difference it runs slower and quieter providing a gentle airflow. At higher speed the cooling might be so great that it negatively affects the performance of the heated bed above.

Print the plastic mount, I used ABS with no support material. There are some overhangs, but they are small and come out fine. PLA should also work, but I think the slight flexibility of ABS gives it the edge for this application.
Attach the top of the fan to the mount with 2 zip ties first. The 2 zip ties used to attach bottom of the fan must also go round the bottom threaded rod of the Printrbot, do this next. Finally wrap 2 zip ties around the middle nubs of the mount and the top threaded rod of the Printrbot - this is incredibly fiddly if the bot is already fully assembled but it is possible, try using pliers, tweezers and patience. Taking off the print bed would make it easier if you're really struggling.
I have provided the SCAD file so that you can change parameters to suit a different fan, but space is very tight down there and I haven't tested any other sizes so check your work!

comments.text: I want to let you know that I was having problems with my printrboard stopping in the middle of my prints, especially on hot days.  As soon as I put a fan blowing on the controller, it started printing fine.  Thanks.
comments.author: douginarug

comments.text:
Really? I have the LC V2 and the same issues. I thought it is a bug in repetierServer (running on a raspberry pi). But I also noticed that the board is extremely hot.
My issues are:
comments.author: douginarug

comments.text: Try it. No harm in extra cooling, and everyone's set-up will be slightly different. You could also try turning down the stepper pots.
comments.author: killi

comments.text: Fantastic, thank you for sharing that! I'd hear of stepper driver chips getting hot and burning out but was told that the Printrboard didn't suffer from this. Interesting to hear otherwise. I'm glad I've been using a fan now that you've confirmed it's useful. One more thing you could try is turning down the trim pots so that less current goes through the stepper drivers as some early Printrboards were set too high (but setting them too low will cause missed steps too).
comments.author: douginarug

The design files for this thing have been removed as a protest against Stratasys after their decision to file a patent infringement lawsuit against Microboards Technology. Their decision is extremely destructive and also underlines that the patent system is obsolete as it no longer serves any purpose for the betterment of society. Its main role is as a blunt weapon used by incumbents to hamper innovation. I see absolutely no reason to continue indirectly supporting Stratasys by providing free content to Thingiverse.

This is a set of accessories that I designed for my Zen Toolworks CNC. 1) Shop vac interface
2) Y-axis homing/limit switch bracket.

Limit-switches for Z & X-axis can be mountet on the original frame without additional support.
The Y-axis limit switch bracket can accomodate a standard arcade style microswitch, and allows for maximum table travel in the Y direction. The vacuum interface allows for a 4 cm diameter flexi tube, but can easily be modified to accomodate other diameters. Use hot glue to secure the flexi tube to interface part d and b. These parts were designed for the 7x7" version. I suspect that they also might fit the 12x12" version, but I haven't verified this. PS. You may need to modify parts a & b slightly if you plan on re-using the original screws for mounting these (I used plastite screws with smaller diameter heads)

comments.text: The design files for this thing have been moved to GitHub: https://github.com/hansj66/Accessories-for-Zen-Toolworks-CNChttps://github.com/hansj66/Acc...

description.text: This thing has moved to Youmagine https://www.youmagine.com/users/jensa so I don't also get sued by Stratasys... At our Oslo hackerspace (Bitraf.no) we needed something to hold PCBs while they were in the PCB tank, so I made this "general purpose PCB holder"

Keep in mind that PLA melts at 60 degrees. I had to use ABS or it would melt when used in the heated PCB tank ( like this one http://www.instructables.com/id/Vertical-Etching-Tank-for-DIY-PCB-etching/ )

remixed_from.author: jbarnhardt
remixed_from.title: FroZen Extruder - alternative Makibox extruder v1.1

description.text:
FroZen body version 1.1, with some trimming to enable further tightening. Earlier Makiboxes have a different gear, which may explain why the standard body hasn't been tight enough. The difference in gears is discussed here:
http://makibox.com/forum/message/13024 See the main FroZen design for more information about how to make and use a FroZen on your Makibox. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/051v82vyutN

comments.text:
This was designed for my printer, which has the the earlier gear (wheel). The standard FroZen never got as much grip on the filament as the standard Zen drive. There's some discussion on that here.
http://www.thingiverse.com/make:67517http://www.thingiverse.com/mak...
It should work on any Makibox that might need a tighter grip than the FroZen.
comments.author: MyMakibox

1) Print out the parts, In fill can choose 30% or up to 50% 2) The camera mount using a round type USB camera. you may need to touch up for your existing one.you also can found the photo with 2 camera. The mount design can allow you using 2 camera if necessary. However, due to the precision, I cannot make too tight fitting indeed. the gap you may add some blu-Tack fill in a bit. then the camera can very secure fixed on the mount. Love you can share with another shape camera mount for this ***Servo mount was deleted, as this is for my first version. this version already skipped saving plastic 3) Some of the holes need touch up, will improve soon. 4) some movie taken and sharing with you
